title: 240+ Fun Truth or Dare Questions for Kids & Families

steps.title: Get to know kids better with these classic truth questions.
steps.content: Get to know kids better with these classic truth questions. Playing “truth or dare” is a fun way to pass the time and bond with kids. Ask questions about their likes and dislikes, secret skills, and any information you’ve been dying to know—it’s one of the best ways to encourage kids to share their thoughts and feelings! Can you keep a secret? What’s your dream job? Do you collect anything? Do you believe in aliens? What’s your favorite food? What’s your favorite animal? What’s your favorite subject? What’s your favorite holiday? Do you have any nicknames? What’s your earliest memory? What’s the name of your crush? Who’s your best friend and why? Do you have any hidden talents? What was your last dream about? Have you ever lied to your parents? Do you believe in any superstitions? Do you have any imaginary friends? What makes you laugh the hardest? What’s your favorite ice cream flavor? What’s your favorite movie or TV show? What’s your favorite thing about yourself? Who are your 3 favorite people in the world? If you were invisible, who would you spy on? Who would play you in a movie about your life? What’s the first thing you want to do after school? If you had to marry a cartoon character, who would it be? What historical figure would you love to meet and talk to? What 3 wishes would you make if you had a magic lamp? If you won the lottery, what’s the first thing would you buy? If you could solve one problem in the world, what would it be?

steps.title: Ask silly or wacky questions to lighten the mood.
steps.content: Ask silly or wacky questions to lighten the mood. The goal of the game is to have fun, so be sure to throw out some lighthearted questions. Funny topics include asking about someone’s best joke, their silliest dream, or the goofiest thing they’ve Googled lately, but feel free to get creative and come up with a wacky “would you rather” question , too! Who’s your least favorite teacher? Have you ever talked to your food? Can you say your name backward? What’s the funniest word you know? What would you do if you had 4 arms? What’s the silliest thing you’re afraid of? What’s the funniest face you can make? What’s the weirdest noise you can make? What’s the best prank you’ve ever pulled? Would you rather eat dog food or cat food? What’s the worst gift you’ve ever received? What’s the funniest joke you’ve ever heard? What would you do if you could talk to cats? What’s the funniest dream you've ever had? What do you think goldfish think about all day? What sound do you think a giraffe should make? What’s the goofiest thing you’ve Googled lately? Would you rather be 3 feet taller or 3 feet shorter? Would you rather always shout or always whisper? What’s the worst time you’ve laughed at something? If animals could talk, which one would be the rudest? Would you rather eat a raw onion or an entire lemon? If you were a clown, what would your clown name be? Would you rather have a flying horse or a talking dog? What’s the most useless piece of information you know? Would you rather talk like Yoda or breathe like Darth Vader? Have you ever pretended to be sick to stay home from school? Would you rather sleep on a mattress made of jello or hot soup? Would you rather have a baseball or a watermelon as your head? Would you rather have gummy bears for toes or french fries for fingers? Would you rather have a cat with a human face or a dog with human hands?

steps.title: Learn more about the other players by asking some slightly personal Qs.
steps.content: Learn more about the other players by asking some slightly personal Qs. If you want to use “truth or dare” to encourage kids to open up, ask them about embarrassing experiences in a fun manner. It’s a great way to teach them how to be vulnerable and not take things too seriously. Relationship coach Laura Bilotta recommends “discussing what topics are off-limits before starting the game” so everyone has a good time. Do you snore? Do your armpits smell? Do you pick your nose? Do you sing in the shower? Do you drool in your sleep? Are you scared of the dark? Have you ever peed in a pool? When’s the last time you cried? Have you ever tasted a booger? Have you ever walked into a wall? Do you sleep with a stuffed animal? What’s your most embarrassing trait? Do you ever talk to yourself in the mirror? What’s your most embarrassing memory? Have you ever had a wardrobe malfunction? What’s the grossest thing you’ve ever done? What’s the most embarrassing photo of you? What’s the weirdest thing you’ve ever eaten? What’s a gross smell that you secretly enjoy? What’s the dumbest trend you’ve ever followed? What’s an embarrassing song you secretly love? What’s an embarrassing movie you secretly love? If you ran out of toilet paper, how would you wipe? What’s the longest you’ve gone without showering? How long have you gone without brushing your teeth? Have you ever laughed so hard that you peed your pants? Have you ever farted in public and blamed someone else? Have you ever tripped and fallen in front of a lot of people? Have you ever accidentally called your teacher “mom” or “dad?” When’s the longest time you’ve left dropped food on the floor before eating it?

steps.title: Suggest hypothetical scenarios for an exciting game of truth or dare.
steps.content: Suggest hypothetical scenarios for an exciting game of truth or dare. If you want to make “truth or dare” even more exciting, come up with a “what-if” style question that’s interesting and creative. It’s a great way to get kids to put on their thinking caps and start a lively discussion! If you could fly, where would you go? If you were an adult for a day, what would you do? If it rained food, what food would you want it to be? If you were president for a day, what would you do? If you were a mad scientist, what would you invent? If you could have any superpower, what would it be? If you could stop time for a year, what would you do? If you could change your name, what would you pick? If all your toys could talk, what would you say to them? If you could meet any famous person, who would it be? If you could master one skill instantly, what would it be? If you could time travel, which decade are you going to? If everything you drew came to life, what would you draw? If you could play any instrument, what would you choose? If you woke up as an animal, what would you be and why? If you could stay one age forever, which would you choose? If the floor was lava, how would you get from place to place? If you could make any kid’s TV show, what would it be about? If you could get rid of one vegetable, what would you choose? If you could only see one color, what color would you choose? If homework didn’t exist, what would you do with that extra time? If you could live in a fictional world, which one would you choose? If you were an Olympic athlete, what sport would you compete in? If we made up our own language, how would we greet each other? If you were born 100 years earlier, what would your occupation be? If you could explore space or the deep sea, which would you choose? If you could eliminate one word from existence, what would it be and why? If you could only watch one movie for the rest of your life, who would you pick? If you could only eat one color of food for the rest of your life, what would it be? If you could have an unlimited supply of one thing for the rest of your life, what would you choose?

steps.title: Stick with these simple dares if you’re feeling bored.
steps.content: Stick with these simple dares if you’re feeling bored. Trying to liven up game night? Look no further—these classic dares are tried and true options! Whether you’re playing with kids, tweens, or teens, here are some iconic dares for a good time: Try to yodel . Do the worm . Make yourself cry. Juggle three objects. Try to lick your elbow. Do 100 jumping jacks. Breakdance for one minute. Talk without moving your lips. Play air guitar for two minutes. Don’t talk for the rest of the day. Write your name using your toes. Do as many push ups as you can. Cover your entire face with lipstick. Go a whole minute without blinking. Don’t say “I” for the rest of the game. Wear a blindfold for the next 20 minutes. Speak in rhymes for the rest of the game. Perform a freestyle rap about your dinner. Recite the alphabet with your mouth closed. Sing all your answers for the rest of the game. Run through a sprinkle with all your clothes on. Talk in a British accent for the rest of the game. Let someone draw a Sharpie tattoo on your arm. Put on as many layers as possible in one minute. Make a concept for a new TV show using your toys. Wave at five strangers the next time you go outside. Hold your nose while talking for the rest of the game. Wear your clothes inside out for the rest of the game. Raise your hands above your head for the rest of the game. Pinch your nose closed and sing the chorus of your favorite song.

steps.title: Come up with a goofy dare to get the giggles going.
steps.content: Come up with a goofy dare to get the giggles going. Looking to make the other players laugh out loud? Ask them to do something silly for a fun time. According to Bilotta, you should “make sure your dare isn’t overly embarrassing or risky” to keep it enjoyable for everyone. Tell a story in a cowboy accent. Let me tickle you for one minute. Pretend to slip on a banana peel. Propose to a pet or stuffed animal. Argue with the couch for 5 minutes. Dance like spaghetti boiling in water. Act like a chicken until your next turn. Try to balance a spoon on your nose. Pretend you’re swimming on the floor. Laugh like an evil villain for 2 minutes. Act like a mime for the next 10 minutes. Call a random contact and start singing. Do a catwalk while making duck sounds. Yell out the first word that comes to mind. Pretend to be a statue until your next turn. Croak like a frog and hop around the room. Act like you’re in a slow-motion movie scene. Pretend to be my pet for the next 10 minutes. Try to spell “Supercalifragilisticexpialidocious.” Lay on the floor and act like a fish out of water. Do your best imitation of everyone in the room. Wear a finger mustache for the rest of the game. Try to whistle a tune with a mouthful or crackers. Act like a jelly bean trying to escape from the jar. Pretend you’re a detective looking for a lost cookie. Draw a face around your belly button and make it talk. Attempt the first TikTok dance on your "For You" page. Try to sell an invisible product to everyone in the room. Pretend you’re an astronaut walking on a squishy planet. Pretend like you’re in a scary movie for the next 30 minutes.

steps.title: Throw out a messy, food-related dare to make things challenging.
steps.content: Throw out a messy, food-related dare to make things challenging. If you’re playing “truth or dare” at home, up the ante by incorporating things in your kitchen or bathroom. Some of these dares can get pretty messy, so make sure you get your parent’s permission and clean up as soon as the game is finished! Bite into an onion. Try to juggle eggs. Take a bite of a lemon. Crack an egg on your head. Try to build a house of cards . Throw on a pair of wet socks. Peel a banana with your toes. Eat a spoonful of crushed garlic. Eat a plate of food with no hands. Put a handful of ice in your pants. Use 3 items in the fridge as lotion. Paint each toe nail a different color. Brush your teeth with peanut butter. Dump a cup of water over your head. Get in the shower with your clothes on. Make a face mask out of cheese slices. Draw a unibrow on yourself with eyeliner. Give yourself a beard with shaving cream. Try to eat a bowl of cereal with chopsticks. Try to balance a cup of water on your head. Apply a face mask made of whipped cream. Wash your hands with butter instead of soap. Stuff as many marshmallows in your mouth as you can. Chug a carbonated drink and burp as loudly as possible. Balance as many crackers on your forehead as possible. Let someone give you a makeover with their eyes closed. Drink a smoothie with 10 random ingredients in your kitchen. Hold your hand in a bowl of ice water for at least 30 seconds. Wrap yourself like a mummy in toilet paper and post a photo of it. Fill your mouth with water and try not to laugh as everyone tells a joke.

steps.title: Think of an out-of-this world challenge to keep everyone entertained.
steps.content: Think of an out-of-this world challenge to keep everyone entertained. Tired of using the same dares for every game? These challenges are unbelievably unique, perfect for kids who’ve played “truth or dare” tons of times. They’re a little more challenging than usual, so be sure to give the other players a pass if they don’t feel comfortable. Suck your big toe. Eat a piece of paper. Sniff someone’s shoes. Post a video of you barking. Sit on a balloon until it pops. Smell another player’s armpit. Draw something and post it online. Kiss the bottom of someone’s foot. Take off your socks with your teeth. Text someone only using your nose. Pick the nose of the person next to you. Declare your love for me on social media. Walk outside and pretend to mow the lawn. Like an old photo on your crush’s Instagram. Film yourself doing your makeup blindfolded. Let the player next to you give you a wedgie. Ask your neighbor if you can borrow 25 cents. Call a pizza place and ask if they sell hotdogs. Let me choose your profile photo for the week. Try to dab up your parents and send me a video. Call your mom and come clean about a childhood lie. Spin around in a circle 10 times then try to walk straight. Go outside and sing “Baby Shark” at the top of your lungs. Go outside and hug your mailbox until 3 cars have passed. Write a breakup message and send it to a random number. Upload a screenshot of a funny wikiHow article on your story. Go on Instagram Live and read the directions on your toothpaste. Pretend you’re a Harry Potter character and make up a new spell. Walk up to an old person on the street and tell her you’re her grandchild. Recite the “how much would a woodchuck chuck” poem really fast while rubbing your belly and patting your head.

steps.title: Take turns asking the players to answer a “truth” or perform a “dare.”
steps.content: Take turns asking the players to answer a “truth” or perform a “dare.” You need at least 2 people to play truth or dare . Once someone has decided on a truth or dare, choose a truth question or dare challenge from the list above. Allow people to “skip” if they don’t feel comfortable, and go around in a circle until everyone has gotten a turn. Generally, it’s more fun if you play with 4-8 players, but you can still have a great time with 2 people. The main goal of the game is to have fun and bond with other players, but you can keep score and offer a small prize at the end for the player who completes the most questions.

steps.title: Can “truth or dare” improve a child’s social skills?
steps.content: Can “truth or dare” improve a child’s social skills? Yes, playing games like “truth or dare” teaches kids to express themselves and respect other people’s decisions. Kids can learn to ask questions that other people will enjoy, helping them consider others’ feelings and boundaries. This also strengthens their friendships and helps them open up and understand people more deeply. [1] X Research source

steps.title: How can I make “truth or dare” more interesting for kids?
steps.content: How can I make “truth or dare” more interesting for kids? You can play outside to add energy to the game, or incorporate props, like hats or balloons, to make the dares more exciting. Alternatively, create themes for each round so the kids have to come up with unique questions. For instance, you could suggest food-related dares or goofy truths for one round.

steps.title: What’s a good age for kids to start playing “truth or dare?”
steps.content: What’s a good age for kids to start playing “truth or dare?” Most kids can start playing “truth or dare” from the age of 7 years old, as long as the questions are simple and the dares are safe. It may help to reassure all the players that it’s okay to skip a question or dare if they don’t feel comfortable, and that the goal of the game is to have fun. [2] X Research source

steps.title: How do I choose the right “truth or dare” questions for kids?
steps.content: How do I choose the right “truth or dare” questions for kids? Tailor questions and dares that align with their age, hobbies, and interests. This makes the game more engaging and ensures everyone has a fun time. You can also ask kids directly for their input, or incorporate hypothetical questions that encourage them use their imagination.
